events_list.audio_caption: A male speaker begins by outlining the purpose of using adaptive triggers to modify application layouts on desktops and phones. He then describes the steps, stating that he will go to the "states pane" and "create a state group". He mentions he will be "adding a couple adaptive triggers". One trigger will be "wide", and the other "narrow".

events_list.video_caption: The video showcases a user working on a Microsoft Blend for Visual Studio project, specifically focusing on a "Hello World" application. The interface displays a design canvas with a white background and a button labeled "button1" positioned at the center. The user interacts with the "StateTriggers Collection Editor State Triggers" window, adding and configuring an "AdaptiveTrigger" with properties such as "MinWidth" set to 302. The user then adjusts the "MinWidth" property to 304 and closes the StateTriggers window. The video continues to show the user making further adjustments to the "MinWidth" property, setting it to 306, and then to 308, while the "Hello World" application remains visible on the design canvas. Throughout the video, the user's actions are focused on modifying the adaptive trigger properties to achieve the desired design outcome. The environment is a typical development workspace with the Microsoft Blend for Visual Studio interface, and the user's actions are methodical and precise, indicating a careful design process.
events_list.audio_caption: A male speaker describes editing and adapting a trigger by adding one and changing the minimum window width to "1024." He mentions a second trigger where he sets the minimum width to "320." He explains that he has told the system to examine the width of the application and adjust the controls' positions based on whether it is greater than "1024." If it is not greater, the system will drop down to the next adaptive trigger and move everything to that location.

events_list.audio_caption: A male speaker begins by saying "Let me show you what I mean" before describing the action of dragging buttons on screen to the left. He then says he will rotate a "hello world" label while holding the shift key, explaining this informs the system that he is working with a wider application, like the "full width of my screen", or over "1024 pixels or wider". As soon as the application is narrow, he wants to see the controls in a different position. To demonstrate, he plays the application locally. By default, the application is large, so everything will display in a wide layout. However, the default width is less than "1024" so it defaults to the narrow layout. As he makes the application wider, crossing the "1024 threshold," the speaker notes that everything moves to the wide position.
